results.title: Rui
results.creator_credit: Film Australia and Social Education Materials Project
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Why can’t they be like we were?”.
Rui is a young adolescent with an industrial inner suburb as a playground. His family does not get away during the school vacation so in order to cope with his environment Rui and his friend Con act out fantasies borrowed from television police dramas. While offering positive criticism on improving the area he also displays how he has been hardened by his environment. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Presidential tour
results.brief_description: The President of the U.S.A., Lyndon B. Johnson, and Mrs. Johnson visit Australia in October, 1966. Scenes in Canberra, Melbourne, Sydney, Brisbane and Townsville.

results.title: Dear mum
results.creator_credit: Don Marley, Peter Johnson, Cinesound Movietone and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A highly entertaining and at times funny film about the life of a young soldier in the army. He writes to tell his mum all the great things that happen in the army - like seeing the country; friendship; a lot of spare time and the satisfaction from working as a group.

results.title: Australian [colour] diary. No. 029
results.brief_description: Shows aspects of Australian life: a report on the Orange (NSW) Field Day where farm equipment is demonstrated to the man on the land and the story of Norfolk Island, home of the descendants of the Bounty mutineers.

results.title: Getting even: women in Australian politics
results.brief_description: In 1894 South Australia became one of the first places in the world to grant women the right to vote and first in the world to allow them to stand as candidates for political office. In 1902, the first Parliament of Australia granted white women the right to vote and to stand for election. Despite this, only 61 women have been elected to Federal Parliament in Australia to date. This film looks at why women’s efforts for greater representation have been continually frustrated, and asks what it is that motivates those women who have made it into the main political game. Female politicians from across the political spectrum talk about their experiences in the ‘boy’s club’ of Australian politics. Australia’s first female Premiers, Carmen Lawrence and Joan Kirner, reflect on their experiences of working at the top of State politics. Bronwyn Bishop, Cheryl Kernot, Amanda Vanstone and others, reveal what lies behind the public face of today’s female politicians. This film also examines the future for women in power, and examines the strategies being used by both major political parties to redress the gender imbalance in our parliaments. The film asks what it really takes for a woman to make it in politics. Has the hard won vote been an effective tool for change or has the political system acted to limit women’s influence? Narrated by Gillian Jones.

results.title: A Race of horses
results.creator_credit: Kit Denton, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Shows without commentary the breeding and training of racehorses in Australia. Includes scenes of foaling, breaking-in and handling the young horses, and an actual race sequence. Photographed by renown cameraman Dean Semler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kit Denton, Don Murray and Film Australia

results.title: Adelaide advances
results.creator_credit: Carl Kayser, Auster Films and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A description of the city and suburbs of Adelaide since foundation. A father is driving his son to one of the research laboratories and as they approach the city, he tells the boy of local industries and the contributions made to the South Australian economy by the Agricultural Research Institute. Includes scenes of the landmarks of the city and a visit to the Onkaparinga Racecourse. Sponsored by the Australian News & Information Bureau and narrated by David Low.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 084
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The following items are featured in this interesting cinemagazine: at Camden Park Dairy, the installation of a Rotolacter has resulted in milking becoming an all mchanical process, setting new standards in hygiene; a Tasmanian factory shows how specialized artists create new effects and manufacture textiles in perfect colour register; to increase friendshp and understanding between neighbours, Malaya and Australia are exchanging Air Cadets.

results.title: Australian diary. No. 088
results.creator_credit: Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A team of women golfers from Britain show their skill on Sydney’s Kensington Links; Trade Unions celebrate the centenary of the movement for shorter working hours - 8 hours work, 8 hours recreation, 8 hours rest; the Valley of Burragorang is deemed to die in the interests of progress - a vast inland sea providing water for Sydney will take possession of the land.
